title: PyAnsys toolkits
text:
PyAnsys toolkits

Contents

PyAnsys toolkits

PyAEDT toolkits

title: PyAnsys toolkits > PyAEDT toolkits
text:
PyAEDT toolkits

PyAEDT Common Toolkit

Shared Ansys Electronics Desktop (AEDT) toolkit components to enable package interoperability and minimize maintenance

https://aedt.common.toolkit.docs.pyansys.com/version/stable/index.html

PyAEDT Antenna Toolkit

Python wrapper for modeling antennas using Ansys Electronics Desktop (AEDT) via PyAEDT

https://aedt.antenna.toolkit.docs.pyansys.com/version/stable/index.html

Magnet Segmentation Toolkit

Python wrapper for automating the segmentation and skew of interior permanent magnet (IPM) and surface permanent magnet (SPM) motors using Ansys Electronics Desktop (AEDT)

https://magnet.segmentation.toolkit.docs.pyansys.com/version/stable/index.html

title: API reference
text:
API reference

The pyansys metapackage on its own does not have a specific API. The only information specific-only
to this package that can be provided is its version. This can be looked up as follows:

However, each of the PyAnsys packages that shape the pyansys metapackage have their own specific API
reference section. In order to navigate through them, please refer to their documentation.

title: User guide
text:
User guide

User guides for the different pyansys packages can be found in their specific documentation.
The pyansys metapackage itself has no functionalities on its own. It is only a bundle of the
different public PyAnsys libraries that are compatible with a given Ansys Unified Install depending
on the version requested.

General purpose

Demo purposes

title: Standalone projects > General purpose
text:
General purpose

Ansys Python Manager

Simple cross-platform QT application to install Python and PyAnsys packages

https://installer.docs.pyansys.com/version/stable/index.html

PyAnsys Cheat Sheets

PyAnsys cheat sheets for different libraries as quick reference guides

https://cheatsheets.docs.pyansys.com/index.html

Ansys 5G Wizard

Ansys project used to calculate Power Density or Cumulative Distribution Function

https://github.com/ansys/5G-Wizard

title: Standalone projects > Demo purposes
text:
Demo purposes

API Eigen Example

Demonstrating the REST and gRPC communication protocols via client-server interactions

https://apieigen.docs.ansys.com/index.html

title: Standalone projects > Repository management
text:
Repository management

Ansys Repository Templates

Ansys tool for creating new projects according to Ansys guidelines

https://templates.ansys.com/version/stable

Ansys GitHub Actions

Collection of GitHub Workflows to be reused by projects in the Ansys ecosystem

https://actions.docs.ansys.com/version/stable

Ansys pre-commit Hooks

Ansys repository containing customized pre-commit hooks

https://pre-commit-hooks.docs.ansys.com/version/stable

Ansys Tools Repository Sync

Ansys tool intended to synchronize the content of two different repositories

https://ansys.github.io/ansys-tools-repo-sync/version/stable

Ansys all-members team

Repository for updating an organization’s all-members team automatically

https://github.com/ansys/ansys-all-members

title: Standalone projects > Artificial intelligence
text:
Artificial intelligence

Reviewer Bot

Python development tool for leveraging the power of OpenAI to automatically generate suggestions for improving GitHub pull requests

https://review-bot.docs.pyansys.com/version/stable/index.html

title: Standalone projects > Documentation
text:
Documentation

Ansys Sphinx Theme

Extension of the popular PyData Sphinx Theme that is used by Numpy, Pandas, PyVista, and many more scientific Python packages

https://sphinxdocs.ansys.com/version/stable/index.html

PyMeilisearch

Enhanced Python API to Meilisearch

https://pymeilisearch.docs.ansys.com/version/stable/index.html

PyConverter-XML2Py

A Python wrapper to convert XML documentation into Python source code with its Sphinx documentation.

https://pyconverter-xml2py.docs.pyansys.com/version/stable/index.html

title: Getting started > Prerequisites
text:
Prerequisites

You need to have the following prerequisites to get started with PyAnsys:

A valid Python version

A licensed version of Ansys

title: Getting started > Prerequisites > Download and install Ansys
text:
Download and install Ansys

Download Ansys software from the Ansys Customer Portal. Ensure you have a
license to use the software.

title: Getting started > Prerequisites > Download and install Python
text:
Download and install Python

Download and install the latest stable version of Python from the
https://www.python.org/downloads.

title: Getting started > Prerequisites > Supported Python versions
text:
Supported Python versions

The PyAnsys ecosystem follows SPEC-0 for Python version support. This
implies that PyAnsys packages drop support for a Python version three years
after their initial release:

In previous diagram:

Python versions in gray are no longer supported

Python versions in light blue are currently supported

Python versions in dark blue are not supported yet

Adoption and deprecation of Python versions in the PyAnsys ecosystem are
tentative. Delays may occur due to third party dependencies.

Below you can find a list of the Python versions supported by each PyAnsys
metapackage release:

title: Getting started > Install PyAnsys
text:
Install PyAnsys

The PyAnsys metapackage is distributed as a Python library. Its installation
follows the standard Python package installation process.

title: Getting started > Install PyAnsys > Online installation
text:
Online installation

Download and install PyAnsys from PyPI:

 Windows



 MacOS



 Linux

text:

title: PyAnsys
text:
PyAnsys

Welcome to the PyAnsys project. While this project originated as a single pyansys package,
it is now a collection of many Python packages for using Ansys products through Python:

title: Examples
text:
Examples

Examples for the different pyansys packages can be found in their specific documentation.

title: Examples > PyAnsys packages examples
text:
PyAnsys packages examples

Combining PyAnsys libraries?

If you are using multiple PyAnsys libraries, you can find examples on how to combine them
in the PyAnsys Workflows page. This page contains
practical examples on how to chain different PyAnsys libraries together.

title: Getting started
text:
Getting started

This page helps you quickly get started with PyAnsys. It lists all the
prerequisites and guides you step by step to install the project on your
platform.

 About PyAnsys

Learn more about PyAnsys and its ecosystem

getting-started/about

 Prerequisites

What you need prior installing PyAnsys

getting-started/prerequisites

 Install

Guidelines on how to install PyAnsys in your system

getting-started/install

title: Tooling libraries
text:
Tooling libraries

Ansys FileTransfer Tool

Simple gRPC API tool for moving files between a client and a remote server

https://filetransfer.tools.docs.pyansys.com/version/stable

Ansys Local Product Launcher

Python utility for launching Ansys products on a local machine and configuring their launch settings

https://local-product-launcher.tools.docs.pyansys.com/version/stable

Ansys Tools Path

Library to locate Ansys products in a local machine

https://path.tools.docs.pyansys.com/version/stable

Ansys Tools Protobuf Compilation Helper

Utility library to compile .proto files to Python source when building the package wheel

https://ansys.github.io/ansys-tools-protoc-helper/

Ansys Tools Visualization interface

Python interface between PyAnsys libraries and plotting backends

https://visualization-interface.tools.docs.pyansys.com/version/stable

PyAnsys Tools Report

Tool for reporting your Python environment’s package versions and hardware resources in a standardized way

https://report.tools.docs.pyansys.com/version/stable

PyAnsys Tools Variable Interop

Tool for defining basic variables, types, metadata, and values intended to provide interoperability between all products

https://variableinterop.docs.pyansys.com/version/stable

PyAnsys Tools Versioning

Tool for backwards and forwards server support

https://versioning.tools.docs.pyansys.com/version/stable

PyAnsys Units

Pythonic interface for units, unit systems, and unit conversions

https://units.docs.pyansys.com/version/stable

PyMaterials Manager

Python package for unifying material management across the Ansys portfolio

https://manager.materials.docs.pyansys.com/version/stable

title: Getting started > About
text:
About

PyAnsys is a collection of Python libraries and tools developed by ANSYS,
Inc. It provides access to Ansys products by using a Python interface,
enabling users to perform engineering simulations, data processing, and
automation tasks.

To ease the installation of the libraries and tools, PyAnsys provides a Python
metapackage. This ensures compatibility between its projects.

title: Getting started > About > Key features of PyAnsys
text:
Key features of PyAnsys

PyAnsys shines in the following areas:

Automation of workflows: PyAnsys enables users to automate repetitive or
complex simulation tasks.

Integration with the Python ecosystem: users can leverage the Python
ecosystem.

Cross-product functionality: PyAnsys provides Python APIs for various
Ansys services and products. By allowing users to interact with multiple
products in a single environment, PyAnsys enables users to streamline their
workflows.

title: Getting started > About > The PyAnsys ecosystem
text:
The PyAnsys ecosystem

PyAnsys libraries can be classified into wrappers and tools.

Wrappers are Python libraries that provide direct access to Ansys products.
Communication between the product and the library is performed via gRPC. Therefore, users can have the product installed remotely and connect
to that remote instance.

Tools are Python libraries that provide additional functionality to the
wrappers.
